title: DIRE Score for Opioid Treatment
description: Predicts compliance with opioid treatment for chronic non-cancer pain

parameters.name: diagnosis
parameters.description: Diagnosis category based on condition severity and objective findings

parameters.name: intractability
parameters.description: Treatment response and patient engagement level

parameters.name: psychological_risk
parameters.description: Psychological risk factors and mental health status

parameters.name: chemical_health_risk
parameters.description: Chemical dependency and substance use history

parameters.name: social_support_risk
parameters.description: Social support system and life stability

ranges.interpretation: Not a suitable candidate for long-term opioid analgesia. Consider alternative pain management strategies, address psychological/social issues, and consider addiction medicine consultation if substance use concerns.
Good candidate for long-term opioid analgesia. May proceed with opioid therapy with appropriate monitoring, treatment agreement, and regular follow-up.

references: Belgrade MJ, Schamber CD, Lindgren BR. The DIRE score: predicting outcomes of opioid prescribing for chronic pain. J Pain. 2006;7(9):671-81.
Chou R, Fanciullo GJ, Fine PG, et al. Clinical guidelines for the use of chronic opioid therapy in chronic noncancer pain. J Pain. 2009;10(2):113-30.
formula: DIRE Score = Diagnosis + Intractability + Psychological Risk + Chemical Health Risk + Reliability Risk + Social Support Risk. Each parameter scored 1-3 points. Total range: 7-21 points.
notes: DIRE stands for: Diagnosis, Intractability, Risk, and Efficacy
Each parameter is scored from 1 (unfavorable) to 3 (favorable)
No prospective external validation exists for this tool
Should be used alongside clinical judgment and other risk assessment tools
American Academy of Pain Medicine has recommended it as a potential tool to assess abuse risk
Higher scores indicate better suitability for opioid therapy
